repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Multi-Mode Transport, Transport
            Rehabilitation, Privatization Support, and Second Public
            Works Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Performance Assessment
            Report (PPAR) covers four recently completed projects for
            the Republic of Yemen.  The ratings of the PPAR generally
            concur with the Implementation Completion Report (ICR)
            ratings, except for the following instances: Multi-mode
            Transport Project- outcome (ICR satisfactory, PPAR
            moderately satisfactory) and sustainability (ICR unlikely,
            PPAR likely); Transport Rehabilitation Project- outcome (ICR
            satisfactory, PPAR moderately satisfactory); Privatization
            Support Project-  Bank and borrower performance, unrated by
            the ICR, in the PPAR they are satisfactory and
            unsatisfactory respectively; and the Second Public Works
            Project - Bank performance (ICR satisfactory, PPAR highly
            satisfactory).  Four primary lessons were learned.  In a
            post conflict, country unification situation additional risk
            analysis is appropriate to ensure that the government is
            fully committed to the reforms proposed and the timetable
            for the reform agenda.  Project objectives should be framed
            realistically, taking into account the borrower's
            ability to achieve stakeholder support for proposed changes.
            Genuine community ownership and participation can enhance
            the likelihood of project success.  Inter-ministerial,
            agency and stakeholder coordination are crucial to project
            sustainability and that the Bank could be more proactive in
            helping to improve the general level of coordination.

            PRIVATIZATION SUPPORT PROJECT,TF040450-REPUBLIC OF YEMEN:
            PRIVATIZATION SUPPORT PROJECT,TF037102-YEMEN - SANA'S WS.,
            NAT'L COM. IMP., PUBLIC WORKS

abstracts.cdata!:
The Privatization Support Project was
            approved on November 30, 1999, with all conditions precedent
            to credit effectiveness completed, except for the
            ratification of the Development Credit Agreement by the
            Yemeni Parliament. Following extensions of the effectiveness
            date, the credit was allowed to lapse at the terminal date
            for effectiveness of April 30, 2001, with no disbursements.
            Despite good progress achieved in readying the project for
            implementation prior to effectiveness, with a new
            privatization law enacted, and implementing institutions in
            place, following the parliamentary elections of 2001, the
            Government however, informed weakness in attaining
            sufficient votes in Parliament to ratify the project by the
            terminal date of effectiveness, given the rising
            contentiousness over privatization in the current
            socio-political environment. The project was thus cancelled,
            although on the Bank's advise, assistance would be
            allowed in funding privatization from other donors, given
            the continued maintenance of institutions established, and
            progress on a number of small enterprise transactions.
            Lessons suggest building adequate support for privatization,
            based on a strong participatory approach involving all stakeholders.

5084668.trustfund:
TF038606-REPUBLIC OF YEMEN:
            PRIVATIZATION SUPPORT PROJECT,TF035163-YEMEN - PRIVATIZATION SUPPORT PROJECT,TF027153-PHRD-PRIVATIZATION TECH.
            ASSIST. PROJECT,TF036585-YEMEN - PRIVATIZATION SUPPORT PROJECT,TF034015-GLOBAL - ENERGY,TF032980-YEMEN - PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT,TF040450-REPUBLIC OF YEMEN:
            PRIVATIZATION SUPPORT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Privatization Support Project, will
            back privatization transactions, raise private enterprise
            efficiency, and reduce the fiscal, and monetary burden of
            the public enterprise sector. The components are: 1) The
            institutional support for program, and project management,
            will provide foreign consulting, technical assistance, and
            training to strengthen the Technical Privatization Office,
            and concerned ministries, in privatization management.
            Construction works will upgrade facilities, and equipment
            supply will be procured. 2) The transactions support for
            large enterprises, include financial/legal advisory services
            for the sale of large scale enterprise assets. Thus, it is
            expected that international consultants will address
            associated policy, and regulatory issues towards competitive
            market practices, on the sale of at least three of the five
            largest government enterprises. 3) The transactions support
            for small, and medium enterprises, will provide financial,
            and legal advisory services, for sale preparations of some
            fifty small/medium enterprise assets, as well as for
            marketing, and procurement of those assets, including the
            necessary associated policy, and regulatory practice
            services. 4) The pre-privatization strategies for large
            enterprises, encompass the process, and methodology for the
            privatization of the five large enterprises, initiating
            comprehensive policy, and institutional frameworks.
